content.title: The Secret Garden, game bar and haven of peace

introduction.small: West of Hanoi in the Da Hong district, The Secret Garden is a café where to relax and play a board game at the same time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Secret Garden, game bar and haven of peace

paragraphs.text:
On the mezzanine, multicoloured pillows have been scattered here and there, giving the café a cosy feel. In Hanoi, The Secret Garden reveals a zen atmosphere, displaying wooden garden furniture, blue shutters and characters drawn on colourful walls. Behind the counter, on the sea-green painting, wooden letters spell the café's name. A truly relaxing outlet in the midst of the urban bustle, the intimate establishment offers fruity refreshments, large smoothies of all colours and flavours (banana, mango, kiwi…), but regulars usually come specially for the dozen games available on the shelves. Local people like to gather in small groups and play Werewolf, Uno, tarot cards or various board games… The Secret Garden is an ideal spot for a friendly and unusual moment, with typical Vietnamese coffee or fresh fruit juice in hand.

content.title: French-Vietnamese stopover at The Clover

introduction.small: In Hanoi's Long Biên neighbourhood, The Clover At Ngoc Thuy offers a French-inspired menu with a few Vietnamese influences.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: French-Vietnamese stopover at The Clover

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by a large green garden, this big white house with turquoise shutters looks impressive, displaying French colonial-style architecture. There, on the banks of the Red River, The Clover invites you to make yourself comfortable. The majestic aspect of the facade is mirrored inside the dining room, where you will find a piano and a real fireplace. If you feel like it, climb up to the rooftop: in a lounge setting, you will enjoy the panorama over Hanoi's skyline and the historic Long Biên Bridge with a drink in hand – to sip on in moderation. Back in the main area, you will be pleasantly surprised by a menu that displays innovative and contemporary French dishes, inspired by traditional recipes. A few Vietnamese touches have been added to the mix, with the use of typical spices. Try the fried duck liver with cuttlefish ink, the grilled pigeon served with mashed marrow in vanilla, or the fillet of turbot with mashed vegetables and passion fruit. These unexpected and elegant pairings will undoubtedly leave a lasting impression.

content.title: Madame Hien Restaurant, Vietnam as seen from France

introduction.small: In Hanoi's Old Quarter, Didier Corlou manages Madame Hien restaurant with virtuosity, in homage to Vietnamese women and their ancestral culinary savoir-faire.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Madame Hien Restaurant, Vietnam as seen from France

paragraphs.text:
Behind the deep golden yellow facade of the establishment, the famous French chef Didier Corlou uses his impressive talent to perfume the streets of Hanoi with his cooking of traditional dishes of Vietnam. Past the entrance portico, you walk into a sober, charming room, enhanced by its colonial heritage. You can dine on the terrace or inside and choose from among the menus proposed or the dishes à la carte.

Away from the hustle and bustle of the capital, the restaurant invites you to indulge in a gourmet excursion in a relaxing atmosphere. Sweet and sour in the south and more rustic in the north, Vietnamese cuisine is very diverse and its cooking has technical characteristics all its own. From caramelized pork meatballs, to green papaya salad with dried beef, and lamb braised with citrus fruit, this is the quintessence of the country's gastronomy, prepared by an excellent French chef.

content.title: Handicraft villages, exceptional savoir-faire

introduction.small: Just a few kilometres outside of Hanoi, many villages continue artisanal traditions. From weaving to pottery to engraving, these skills are the daily life of their inhabitants. Tempted to visit?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Handicraft villages, exceptional savoir-faire

paragraphs.text:
Escape from the centre of Hanoi for a moment if the effervescence of the tourists is tiring you out. Are you on a search for the uniqueness of Vietnam? Spread out through the four corners of the city and its surrounding countryside, the handicraft villages transmit their traditional artisanal knowledge from generation to generation. Here are our recommendations.

In the Phuong Trung township, Chuông is one of the oldest villages in the country making the omnipresent Vietnamese conical hats. On the right bank of the Nhûe river, Dong Cuu does a vibrant business in clothing for traditional festivals with royal and chivalrous embroidery. For nearly two centuries, Ha Thai has worked with lacquer in the Thuong Tin district—disrupting the legacy of daring techniques, artisans now export products known for their quality to Europe. In Bat Trang, pottery is in the spotlight among the residents living near the Red River—perhaps you will be tempted to try to make your own! Finally, in Ha Dong province, the village of Van Phuc works with silk: breeding worms, spinning, weaving and dyeing.

content.title: Home: a Vietnamese restaurant in a traditional house

introduction.small: Unaltered charm is a delight to be savoured at Home, a contemporary Vietnamese restaurant in the style of an authentic family home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Home: a Vietnamese restaurant in a traditional house

paragraphs.text:
This French colonial style building, which survived the devastating bombing of the last two wars, is one of the city's best preserved. At the corner of a quiet lane in the quiet neighbourhood of Truc Bach, between the Old Quarter and the vast expanse of West Lake, this house has defied time for more than a century. Inhabited today by the chef of the contemporary Vietnamese restaurant, Home, and his team, the house has lost none of its authenticity.

Inside, brick walls, wooden carved panels, and windows with faded wood frames form the backdrop for a decor awakened by contemporary furniture. It is the same with the restaurant's inventive cuisine, which features traditional dishes revisited with modern touches. You will love the sautéed clams in garlic, chili sauce and coconut milk, or the boiled pork chops in curcuma served with eggplant.

content.title: Good Morning Vietnam at Bun cha Huong Liên

introduction.small: It's possible to enjoy a popular dish in the place where it came from. Just enter this restaurant, visited by President Obama.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Good Morning Vietnam at Bun cha Huong Liên

paragraphs.text:
In North Vietnam, bun cha is made of rice vermicelli (bun) and fried or grilled hash (cha). In Hanoi, besides the vermicelli, bun cha consists of pork, minced or cut into strips and grilled over charcoal or cooked in a pan. In the south, the meat is marinated with lemongrass and garlic and enriched with herbs, and then served with salad and a bowl of sweet and sour fish sauce.

On an official visit to Vietnam, US President Barack Obama immortalised Bun cha Huong Liên by having the famous bun cha with food writer Anthony Bourdain along with a Vietnamese beer straight from the bottle.

content.title: Bamboo Bar: legendary cocktails in a legendary palace hotel

introduction.small: Let yourself be carried away by the quaint charm of this bar, whose timelessness tells the story of the Sofitel Legend Metropole, an exceptional palace hotel and a true institution.

paragraphs.text:
In luxury hotels, bars maintain the legend. And the Sofitel Legend Metropole contributes to the myth. The Bamboo Bar holds many secrets under its traditional thatched roof: the secrets of anonymous travellers as well as those of the celebrities who stayed here. The Graham Greene martini, in homage to the writer who wrote several chapters of The Quiet American during his visit here in the 1950s, is the bar's signature cocktail. Charlie Chaplin also stayed here during his honeymoon following his secret marriage to Paulette Goddard.

In the bustle of the city, the Bamboo Bar is a tranquil enclave where the charm and sweetness of life is tasted with relish. At the pool or under the wicker fans that stir the air in the quiet room, one eats ice cream or drinks fruit juice, one of the famous Metropole teas, an aromatic coffee or a delicious cocktail accompanied by a light snack.

content.title: Several bites of legend at Cha Ca La Vong

introduction.small: This old Hanoi tavern has become legendary thanks to Cha Ca (fried fish), the unique dish that gives it its name.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Several bites of legend at Cha Ca La Vong

paragraphs.text:
There is a dish served at Cha Ca La Vong whose recipe has been passed down from generation to generation within the Doan family, and which can be found in all Vietnamese gastronomy books: Cha ca. It consists of filets of monkfish or firm and tasty Lang fish (hemibagrus) cut into chunks, marinated in Indian saffron powder, and fried over a wood charcoal grill.
It is served with cold rice noodles, roasted peanuts, herbs (basil, cilantro, dill) and baby onions, and eaten with mâm tôm (shrimp paste). This recipe makes the legendary Cha Ca La Vong a gastronomic destination in old Hanoi. It has a rustic Vietnamese family atmosphere far from the tourist crowds.

content.title: Hôi An: authentic charm in a picturesque and mesmerising village

introduction.small: At night, silk lanterns bring even more magic and mystery to the old town of Hôi An, listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôi An: authentic charm in a picturesque and mesmerising village

paragraphs.text:
In a place where time has no hold, the temples, pagodas, communal and family houses, and shops convey this city's past. The oldest part of the city lies along the banks of the Thu Bon River. Further west, the Japanese district with its amazing covered pagoda bridge reflects the rich cultural exchange of what was once one of the main commercial ports of Southeast Asia. Most of the older homes, recognisable by their wooden beams, carved doors, and spacious rooms opening onto courtyards, have been converted into craft and souvenir shops, and restaurants. While in Hôi An have the favourite pieces of your wardrobe remade by tailors, but be careful about negotiation and finishes. Only a few kilometres from Hôi An, beautiful, relaxing beaches await you.

content.title: The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology and its 54 ethnic groups

introduction.small: Further out from the city centre, the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is worth visiting for its unique view of the culture and lifestyle of many Vietnamese communities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology and its 54 ethnic groups

paragraphs.text:
Over the centuries and with each successive invasion, the Vietnamese have had increasingly mixed ethnic roots. The Kinh now cohabitate with various ethnic minorities, from the mountaineers of the high northern plateaux to the Cham and the Khmer. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology celebrates their traditions in a three-hectare space.
The crafts, traditional costumes, musical instruments, life-size reproductions of village community houses, folklore, and traditional customs of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam are all represented. Communities play an important role in the history of the museum as they contribute fully to the preparation of exhibitions and participate in numerous events, such as craft demonstrations and traditional games, giving added meaning to the museum's vocation.

content.title: The One Pillar Pagoda: an architectural wonder

introduction.small: In the Ba Dinh district, in the west of Hanoi, the One Pillar Pagoda rising out of a pond symbolises a sacred lotus springing from an ocean of suffering.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The One Pillar Pagoda: an architectural wonder

paragraphs.text:
This uniquely structured small Buddhist temple has become a symbol of the city. Originally built at the request of King Ly Thai To, this original wooden pagoda celebrates the goddess who brought him news of the birth of his son, presented on a lotus flower. This is why its original architecture evokes the sacred flower.

Built on a single pillar, the pagoda is surrounded by a lush, verdant Zen garden. It appears to float above the small pond, whose waters ripple with swimming carp. Destroyed in 1954 by a French bomb, the pagoda was rebuilt by the new Vietnamese government. Young couples seeking Buddha's blessing to have children bring offerings of fruit and incense to the altar inside.

content.title: The Puppet Theatre on water: folk immersion

introduction.small: In this famous theatre on the banks of the Lake of the Restored Sword, puppets and carved wood dragons bring regional legends to life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Puppet Theatre on water: folk immersion

paragraphs.text:
The stage looks like a pond from which lacquered wooden dolls emerge. Submerged in water up to the waist and hidden behind a screen, puppeteers manipulate figures using long bamboo rods. The grandiose show is accompanied by a traditional orchestra that sits on the side of the stage. The explosions of firecrackers herald key moments in these enchanted stories in which characters appear or disappear like magic.

The show unfolds as a series of tableaux, evoking both legends and scenes of everyday life that explain the origins of a phenomenon. The Thang Long Theatre at the Lake of the Restored Sword right at the entrance to the Old Quarter is one of the best places to discover this authentic art. Originally created by peasants in the Red River region, this spectacle, whose ancestral traditions date back to the 11th century, is one of the major art forms of Vietnam.

As the story goes, the small islands and eroded limestone peaks in the bay were formed from fragments of jade and gems that sprung from the water when a dragon plunged into it. In this wide cove, a treasure trove of more than 3,000 mostly uninhabited limestone islets punctuate the surface of the indigo sea.

Strangely shaped rock sculptures and caves carved into cliffs transport you into a magical world where time has stopped. The strange and fantastic forms of these rocky peaks are worth taking the time to visit. A cruise of several days will take you to the bay's lagoons and pristine beaches. Stretching out over 1,500 square kilometres, it takes you far from traditional tourist haunts. Whether on a deluxe junk or a less expensive seafaring craft, embark on a cruise through this dream setting for a unique journey.

content.title: The Victoria Express Train is a memorable journey through time

introduction.small: At Hanoi Railway Station, climb aboard this authentic train and travel to Sapa through the breath-taking scenery of northern Vietnam. A unique and nostalgic experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Victoria Express Train is a memorable journey through time

The dream lasts eight hours and 30 minutes, long enough for a good night's sleep in one of the stylish Art Deco wagons. Like an Agatha Christie novel, the cosy rooms, with mahogany panelling and crimson silk, create an intriguing atmosphere. It hearkens back to a time when travel was an art form. The refined Le Tonkin dining car is part of this timeless experience. Through the large windows, the wild and untamed landscape of the northwest region whips by, defying us to attempt its roads.

The Victoria Express Train travels between Hanoi and Lao Cai six times a week. Here, the mountains are higher, the hills steeper, and the forests denser. content.title: The Old Quarter: a maze of ‘36 Streets'

introduction.small: Hold your breath before crossing the narrow streets of the Old Quarter. Proceed slowly but surely. Though motorcyclists often ride on the sidewalks, they won't knock you over.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Old Quarter: a maze of ‘36 Streets'

paragraphs.text: North of the lake, between the river and the citadel, this lively neighbourhood was one of the main bastions of resistance in the colonial era. It is still the heart of the city. Different artisanal trades have gathered together here in these 36 quaint streets since the 13th century. Names like Bamboo Basket Street and Tin Street no longer exclusively reflect the kinds of craftsmen in these streets; nonetheless, the spirit of camaraderie still lives on because stores that specialise in similar things gravitate towards each other. Thus, what was formerly known as Hemp Street has now been taken over by silk-fabric shops. The ‘Street of Oil Sellers' now hosts shoe stores. The street spectacle in the Old Quarter is unique and fascinating. Lose yourself in the neighbourhood while exploring, but remember to obey the rules of the road…

content.title: The Temple of Literature: academy of mandarins

introduction.small: Regarded as the first university in Vietnam, the Temple of Literature hosted future leaders of the nation, who followed the teachings of Confucius.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Temple of Literature: academy of mandarins

paragraphs.text:
An inscription on one of the temple pillars perfectly captures the spirit of this site: ‘Confucianism lies everywhere, east, west, south and north. Dignitaries and scholars have all followed the same path.' Founded in 1070, during the reign of King Ly Thanh Tong, this building, dedicated to Confucius, was originally the school of the nation's elite, where students aspiring to become bureaucrats followed a rigorous three-year education.
With five courtyards, the vast grounds of the Temple of Literature are in the heart of the capital. They constitute an entirely unique enclave. It is impossible to visit Hanoi without spending some time this grandiose site. The Gate of Talents, the Sanctuary of Success, and the Pavilion of the Constellation of Literature are surrounded by lavish landscaped gardens that preserve the authenticity of the legend.

content.title: Lake of the Restored Sword: a legendary walk

introduction.small: The island of the tortoise in the middle of the lake celebrates the sacred animal, which, according to legend, gave King Le Thai To the liberating sword against Chinese occupiers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lake of the Restored Sword: a legendary walk

paragraphs.text:
A stroll on the shady banks of the Lake of the Restored Sword, also called Green Lake, is an unparalleled way to experience the charms of the city. Everyday life begins with early morning tai chi sessions and badminton games, and is animated by loud music and balloon-sellers in the evening.

Sit on the terrace of a café nearby to enjoy the spectacle of the lake, the scene of the incredible legend. Here, King Le Thai To, founder of the 15th-century dynasty, received a magical sword from a turtle that helped him free his country after ten years of Chinese rule. At the northern tip of the lake, the lacquered red Bridge of the Rising Sun is striking. Cross over it to visit the Temple of Jade Mountain on the island.

content.title: The Imperial City: journey to the court of the mandarins

introduction.small: Behind eight-metre-high, ten-kilometre-long walls, the Kinh Thanh Citadel stands on the left bank of Perfume River in Huê.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Imperial City: journey to the court of the mandarins

paragraphs.text:
The construction of the fascinating Imperial Citadel began in 1805, based on the model of the Beijing citadel, during the reign of Emperor Gia Long. The Nine Canons of Deities stand guard at the threshold to this day. Everyone must go through the Meridian Gate to reach the other buildings. With its five entry points, the gate's yellow and green-tiled Five Phoenix belvedere is instantly recognisable.

Past this gate, the Bridge of Golden Waters, once reserved for the emperor, leads to the Palace of Supreme Harmony. The Forbidden Purple City, where only the emperor and his family had the right to enter, extends over the third and final wall. A UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1993, the Imperial City has lost none of its charm. In the Royal Theatre, traditional music concerts dating back to the court of Huê are still performed.

content.title: La Badiane: a unique dining experience in Hanoi

introduction.small: Founded in 2008 by three French friends, La Badiane has become a gastronomic reference whose famous fusion cuisine transcends borders.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Badiane: a unique dining experience in Hanoi

paragraphs.text:
La Badiane is one of those dream places one stumbles across with delight. To get to it, one takes a poetically overgrown paved lane. The stage is set for a decor of elegant simplicity. On the ground floor of this contemporary two-floor bistro, large volumes emphasise a feeling of tranquillity.

In the kitchen, chef Benjamin Rascalou, one of the restaurants' three founders, prepares an inventive cuisine fusing flavours and spices particularly dear to him. As with the many discoveries that punctuate a trip, dishes revealed and heightened by spices tell many stories that merge in the mouth: shrimp with a sweet potato mousseline, roasted lamb shank with lemon and rosemary, tabbouleh and cinnamon raita, as well as grilled salmon fillet in smoked paprika, zucchini and cauliflower cannelloni.
A meal at La Badiane is a unique Hanoi dining experience that will leave beautiful memories.
